Item.Title: Four Short Films On The Godfather
The Godfather On The Red Carpet
1917 Fanucci Attacked
Item.Description: Young Vito witnesses three young thugs teaching Fanucci a lesson by cutting his throat, but not to the point of killing him. This scene would have played between the first long scene involving Fanucci at the theater, and Vito's decision to murder him.

Item.Title: 1917 Clemenza: "I'm My Own Boss"
Item.Description: The Young Clemenza tries to impress Vito, who will see him as a useful ally and, eventually, caporegime.

Item.Title: 1917 Playing The Flute
Item.Description: Vito accompanies Clemenza and Tessio to a local gunsmith, whose son plays the flute for the visitors. This is an affectionate tribute to Francis Coppola's father, Carmine, who became first flautist with the NBC Symphony under Arturo Toscanini. Carmine Coppola's father Augustino was also a gunsmith. After the visit to the gunsmith, young Clamenza fences stolen dresses to a young woman.

Item.Title: 1917 Discussing Fanucci
Item.Description: Fanucci tries to intimidate Vito, who then discusses the problem with Clamenza and Tessio. This conversation would have merged with the scene in Part II wher Vito informs his friends that he will offer Fanucci much less than his demands.

Item.Title: 1917 Reasoning With Signor Roberto
Item.Description: This merely extends the conversation between Vito and Signor Roberto in the street, emphasizing the young immigrant's affable, "reasonable" approach that conceals a calculating and potentially ruthless mind.

Item.Title: 1917 Don Vito Corleone
Item.Description: This serves as an introduction to the scene in Part II where Signor Roberto agrees to Vito's request to reinstate his tenant. But it also happens to include the first reference to "Don Vito Corleone."

Item.Title: 1918 Introducing Hyman Roth
Item.Description: Hyman Roth, so prominent in the "modern" segmants of Part II, figures nowher in the early scenes, save this brief meeting, where Vito bestows a new name upon him. There's also a sly reference to the scene in Roth's den in Miami, when Michael learns that Roth has liked baseball "ever since Arnold Rothstein" fixed the World Series in 1919.

Item.Title: 1927 Vito's Revenge
Item.Description: Between the sequence at the alfresco luncheon in Sicily, and the stroll through the wine cellar, this scene shows Vito murdering two of DOn Ciccio's thugs in revenge for the death of his parents - and before Vito attacks the aged Mafia chieftain himself.

Item.Title: 1945 The Death of Genco
Item.Description: Immediately following Connie's wedding, the Don takes his sons to pay their final respects to Genco Abbandando, Vito Corleone's first business partner and consigliere. Genco is played by Franco Corsaro (who otherwise does not feature in The Godfather)

Item.Title: 1945 A Gift From Woltz
Item.Description: In the theatrical release of The Godfather, Woltz first appears at the end of this scene. The reference to the leering Woltz giving a pony to 12-year-old "Janie" would be meaningless without the shots of Hagen seeing Janie at the producer's mansion later that evening.

Item.Title: 1945 Hagen Sees Janie
Item.Description: Hagen is shocked to see Janie and her mother at Woltz's mansion, and realizes that services have been brutally rendered in exchange for the gift of the pony. This brief, but telling scene would have been inserted immediately after Hagen leaves Woltz's dining room to drive to the airport.

Item.Title: 1945 A Family Fight
Item.Description: This scene of Carlo and Connie quarrelling was considered redundant in view of the extensive footage already devoted to their fights. Hagen's references to Janie and Woltz had to be cut once a decision had been made to eliminate the incident altogether.

Item.Title: 1945 Michael and Kay In Bed
Item.Description: This scene, which appeared in the TV version of The Godfather Saga, definitely adds a certain relaxed, almost carefree dimension to the initial relationship between Michael and Kay Adams. It precedes the shots of the couple leaving Radio City Music Hall.

Item.Title: 1945 The Don's Been Shot...
Item.Description: This, and the following deleted sequence, would have fleshed out Sonny's role more significantly, analyzing his reactions to the news of his father's having been shot and the responsibility that this is likely to force upon him.

Item.Title: 1945 Sonny Absorbs The News
Item.Description: A revealing sequence showing Sonny's reluctance to assume the role of the Don (note the glance he gives his father's chair before sitting beside the desk), and also the resignation with which Mama Corleone takes the news of the shooting.

Item.Title: 1945 Michael Gets Involved
Item.Description: Theresa Hagen appears very briefly in The Godfather. In this scene she is comforted by Michael, who then talks to Sonny with something of the same quiet, burgeoning authority of his father. At the end of the scene, a shaken Tom Hagen returns after being set free by Sollozzo.

Item.Title: 1945 Planning Paulie's Death
Item.Description: This scene articulates what in the finished film is merely implied, although Rocco Lampone's character takes on a slighly more distinctive profile.

Item.Title: 1945 Clemenza Eats Lunch
Item.Description: Following immediatly after the previous deleted scene, this sequence shows Clemenza hanging Paulie out to tdry before his execution, saying that he has to call Sonny but in fact settling down to a relaxed lunch at his favorite Italian restaurant.

Item.Title: 1947 Communist Demonstration
Item.Description: Michael is puzzled by a parade of Communist workers through the Sicilian countryside. In historical fact, these men would have been mowed down by Salvatore Guiliano and his mafiosi. The sequence also elaborates on the character of Michael's bodyguards, and hints Fabrizio's likely treachery in the future.

Item.Title: 1947 Seeking Vito's House
Item.Description: Michael strolls through Corleone, looking for the house his father lived in as a child before his flight to America.

Item.Title: 1947 Yelling In The Shower
Item.Description: Connie accuses Carlo of yet another infidelity. This scene, although quite powerful, even operatic, appeared redundant in view of the long quarrel scene between Carlo and Connie that already features in The Godfather.

Item.Title: 1947 "Bring Me Fabrizio"
Item.Description: Michael's anguish at the loss of Apollonia is manifest here, but also his ruthless instinct for immediate vengeance.

Item.Title: 1948 Talking In The Garden
Item.Description: A significant and poignant conversation between Michael and his increasingly detached father. Michael makes plain his intention to avenge the deaths of Sonny and Apollonia, and the Don, who has sworn not to break the peace, accepts that his son can take responsibility for doing so.

Item.Title: 1948 Hagen: "Why Am I Out?"
Item.Description: When Hagen learns that Rocco Lampone and Al Neri are reporting directly to Michael, he confronts his brother, with Don Vito in the room. Michael's final sentance, "You're not a wartime consigliere, Tom," is a harbinger of his vengeance against the other families.

Item.Title: 1955 Kay Lights Candles
Item.Description: The original novel by Mario Puzo ends with a similar scene (showing Kay taking communion and praying for Michael's soul). Mario Puzo's The Godfather: The Complete Novel for Television concluded with this scene, which explains the presence of the credit crawl.

Item.Title: 1958 Fredo and Deanna
Item.Description: This scene shows Fredo and Deanna arriving late for Anthony's communion celebrations. It resembles a subsequent scene in Part II of an embarrasing public spat between Fredo and his wife.

Item.Title: 1958 No Champagne Cocktails...
Item.Description: Pentangeli refuses a waiter's offer of champagne cocktails, which in turn anticipates the argument between him and Michael when Pentangeli refers to the kind of drinks being served at teh party.

Item.Title: 1958 Francesca To Marry
Item.Description: Francesca, twin daughter of Sonny, visits Michael with her mother at the Lake Tahoe compound, to ask his permission to marry. Michael's warm acceptance of the fiance, Gardner Shaw, contrasts sharply with the scene in Part II where Connie introduces Merle Johnson to Michael.

Item.Title: 1958 Fabrizio Located
Item.Description: This scene was abandoned, in tandem with the later one showing Fabrizio's murder. Michael's memory in identifying his first wife's killer after more than a decade recalls his father's unerring ability to track down his parents' assassins when visiting Sicily.

Item.Title: 1958 Anthony And Pentangeli
Item.Description: Despite having two of his scenes left on the cutting-room floor, Michael V. Gallo still earned an Academy Award nomination for his performance as Pentangeli. Here he slips a $100 bill to Anthony in a gesture of affectionate, yet somehow careless generosity.

Item.Title: 1958 Neri Humiliates Klingman
Item.Description: Michael's enforcer, Al Neri, is seen here confronting a recalcitrant casino-owner in front of his clientele, and then chasing him through the Las Vegas hotel until his victim agrees to quit.

Item.Title: 1958 Murder of Fabrizio
Item.Description: This scene would appear right after Neri's humiliation of Klingman, and before the scene in Part II where Michael finds Anthony's drawing on his pillow. We know that the murder occurs in Buffalo because in the scene "Fabrizio Located," Al Neri states that the Sicilian has been found there.

Item.Title: 1979 The Godfather Part III: Alternate Opening Sequence
Item.Description: The following rough footage shows how Coppola originally intended to open Part III. It reflects the tone and technique of the first sequence in The Godfather, wich the camera retreating slowly from the Archbishop's face over the shoulder of a seated Michael Corleone. Coppola subsequently felt that Part III should commence on a note of family - not business. An abridged version of this scene now occurs further into the film.

Item.Title: 1901 Searching for Vito
Item.Description: Don Ciccio's men conduct a house-to-house search for Vito following the murder of his brother Paolo.

Item.Title: On Location
Item.Description: The Godfather films were shot primarily in real world locales rather than on studio back lots. Production Designer Dean Tavoularis returns to the Lower East Side of Manhattan and takes us on location.

Item.Title: Music of The Godfather: Nino Rota
Item.Description: In January of 1972, Francis Coppola travelled to Rome to meet with the great composer and Fellini collaborator Nino Rota. Coppola had his new portable tape recorder with him and he captured this meeting.

Item.Title: Music of The Godfather: Carmine Coppola
Item.Description: Carmine Coppola collaborated on the soundtrack for all three Godfather films. We visit with Maestro Coppola conducting the score for Part III while hearing recollections of the Maestro's son, Francis.

Item.Title: The Godfather Part II, Best Director 1974
The Godfather Part II, Best Picture 1974
Capturing The Corleones: Through the Lens of Photographyer Steve Shapiro
The Godfather Part II: Scan Element Comparisons
